div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,239] ALEXANDRIA, Monday, FEBRUARY 12, 1906. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL, Cairo
div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. Stands in its own grounds with garden and lawn tennis grounds at back. Over 350 rooms and 5 saloons. Magnificent salle à manger. Handsome covered promenade verandah, 80 yards long. Highest class cuisine, electric light throughout, and lifts. English comforts. Rooms and apartments at prices to suit everyone. For further particulars apply to GENERAL MANAGER, Cairo.

The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.

Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.

div.head: THE POSTAL ADMINISTRATION
div.p: The new regulation of the Postal Admi-nistration that all letters not fully sdd*e«- sed will be retained till the next delivery is a very good one, so far as it toonoemi letters for those whose addresses are not well-known, but to make it a hard and fast rale, and to retain letters addressed to trainees firm* of long standing, and whose addresses are perfectly well known, seems to u a most unjustifiable measure. No doubt most of the correspondents of suoh firnu have been advised to address their letter! , fully, but some of those that have been in the habit of patting only "Alexandria" or Z "Cairo" on their letters for the last ten of twenty years or more, from* sheer force .of ' habit, will probably forget to fully address them, for which the receivers cannot be blamed. Are they to be punished by having their letters willfully withheld for so many hoars 1 when in many inatanoes jt is of the utmost importance that they should be received at the earliest possible moment. Again take the thousands of letters addressed to passengers and sailors, hardly any of which have more than "Alexandria" on them, addressed to the* oare of tba Steam* t ship Agents. Are . -all these letters to be delayed, when it is often a question of a few hours of their either remaining in Alexandria, or of their sailing, and b| this detention the letters may be delayed not hours, but weeks, before they reaoh their proper destination I We oomider -that the Postal Authorise* j are assuming a great responsibility in thus willfully detaining Utters, for which'jhb only exora?'. tbs? oan make is that they wish to forcr other people whose add ret: 368 ate not w«ji, known to tally address their letters. will* venture to say this is the only Oummeroie* town where snob a regulation, is in furou, aud were it to be attempted in any town in the United Kingdom ^i Europe, it would not be tolerated for a moment' It is to be regretted that the Postal Admi-nistration, which has in many ways shown itself one of the most enlightened ot all the Egyptian Administrations, should have (n . - this instance lent itself to such a very sr- bitrary measure, and we can only hope that they will toon see their way to put an end to suoh a very vexatious one.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: Yesterday opened with a light breeze from the N.N.E. but towards noon the wind suddenly changed to the N.N.W. The day was rather warm, but becme beautifully cool in the evening. Barometer steady.

table.head: OTHER STATIONS.
For the 24 hours ending 3 a.m. Yesterday

div.head: Alexandria Harbour.
div.p: The Ports and Lighthoueea Administration has just received its tenders for the oonstruotion of two breakwaters to enolose the outer harbour. There were three offers, Messrs. Almagia, Benoini and Qaista, and Wills and Company.

div.head: North Egypt Land Co.
div.p: The committee of the London Stook Ex* change has fixed February 16th as a epeoial settling day in North Esypt Land Company, Ltd. lOO/'OO shares of £1 each, fully paid, Nos. 1 to 100,000.

div.head: Fugitives to Egypt.
div.p: Warrants have been issued in Constantinople for the arrest of two Armenians, Takfor and Serk z, by name, both natives of Tohorlou. These men left for Egypt shortly after the attempted assassination of the Sultan last July.

div.head: Wakfs Administration.
div.p: Abdel Halim Pacha Assem, Director General of the Administration, has requested the Khedive, to permit him to retire on pension. His resignation is said to have been accepted ; and his successorwill be appointed after his Highness's return froUkhis trip.

div.head: The Olympic Games.
div.p: Yesterday Mr. LambnJs, the General Secretary of the Olympic Games Committee, addressed a meeting of the Greek Colony of Alexandria at the Averoff School on the snbjeot of the furthcoming oelebration of the games at Athens.

div.head: Motors at Alexandria.
div.p: A letter which we print to-day from "A Sufferer," contains a much-needed protest against the utter disregard of consideration for others, shown by so many motorists. Many complaints have lately been made by residents in Rosetta street ot annoyance experienced, especially late at night, by these very inconsiderate disturbers of the peace.

div.head: The Austrian Ball.
div.p: The Austro-Hungarian Benevolent Society's annual ball was given at the New Khedivial Hotel on Saturday evening, and was largely attended, the complete laok ot cabs in no way preventing people from turning op. Some 600 were present. Soon after midnight sappers were served, and the dining rooms became orowded. Danoing continued till the early hours of the morning.

div.head: New Line to Egypt
div.p: The Rumanian Steamship Company has ordered a new steamer, to be named the Daoia, of the Chantiera de La Loire. This vessel which is to be placed on the projeoted Alex andria line is to be of the type of the Transatlantic liners. The Company has farther decided to order two cargo-boats, of 6,000 tons displacement, which will be built at Kiel or Liverpool. It further proposes establishing a regular servioe between Constanza and Man- galia.

div.head: The Serato Concert.
div.p: This evening the oelebrated violinist Serato will give a concert at the New Khedivial Hotel at Alexandna.The following is the programme: Wieniawski: Second Concert poor Violon, avec aocomt de Piano. Allegro moderate, Romance, Finale alia zingara. Rachmaninoff: . Prelude en Do diate mineur, pour piano. Chaminade : Toooaia op. 3$ pour piano. Jarne- feld: Berceube pour violon, ayeo acoomt. de piano. Ries : Perpetuum mobile aveo aocomt de piano. Baoh : Air sur la quatrifeme ooide avec aocomt. de piano, Sarasate : Zigeuueiwei- sen aveo accumt. de piano.

div.head: Egyptian Government buys Consols.
div.p: The Egyptian Government baa invested about a million and a half sterling in Consols and similar securities. The Egyptian Govern-ment is entitled, as our reader* are aware, to a share in the profits resalting from the Daira transaction. As the transaction is now nearly completed, a portion of the share of the profits to which it is entitled has been paid to the Government, and having no immediate use for the money, it has made an investment of it as stated. There have been other large purchases of consols-, and the price has moved upwards, but not as much as, under the ciicumstanoes, might have been expected.

div.head: The Grant Bey Papyri.
div.p: In the latest issue of the Revue des Etudes Urt^ues there is an artiole by M. Thdodore Reiuach on one of the papyras fragments in the Grant B«y collection presented to Aberdeen U.iive£sity some years ago by the widow of Dr. Grant Bey, of Cairo. Early last year the fragment was seen by Dr. Grenfell to be lyiijul in character, and Mr. E. (). Wm-tflHt, Ot tic. Andrew's Uuiversity, placed itdtfiuitely si belonging to Alcteus. M. Reinaoh supports thia view, on the ground of a refereuoe to the famous tyrant Myrsilus. The fragment, which eonaiata of ten lines, is aboht 2| in. by 3 in. it is the first of the olassioal pieces in the collection which has been fairly identified

div.head: NATIONAL BANK OF EGYPT
div.p: THE GOVERNORSHIP
LORD CROMER MEETS DIRECTORS.

An important meeting was held this morning when Lord Cromer saw four of the directors of the National Bank of Egypt Boghos Paoha Nnbar, Mr. Foster, Mr. F. Snares and Mr. Zervadaohi, who conferred with his Lordship on the subject of a successor to the late Sir Elwin Palmer as Governor of the Bank.

Lord Cromer received Sir Vinoent Caillard this morning at the British Agenoy. As we have already announoed Sir Vincent is the favourite in London, and is supportel by the infiuenoe of Sir Ernest Cassel and of the London Agenoy. But some of the local Board of Directors prefer another candidate, and won Id* like to see Chitty Bey, the Director General of the Customs Administration, take the post.
The seleotion ultimately rests with the Egyptian Government which has the right of veto. No final decision will be arrived at for a few days.

The new governor, in lien of a house, will probably have an allowance of £1,00 » per annum. The board will not allow him to go in for any other outside business without their express oonseut But of oourse the new governor will be ohairman of the Abyssinian Bank and of the Agricultural Bank of Egypt A salary of £5u0 per annum and £1,200 per annum are attached lespectively to ihe«e positions.

div.head: WALKER AND MEIMARACHI, LTD.
div.p: The new issue of 10 ,0C0 ordinary £1 shares in the above company has been a great success, and was over subscribed for. Letters of allotment and regret will be issued shortly. It is intended to proceed at once with the eon struotion of the company's new premises at the junction ot Sharia el Manakh and Sharia el-Madebergh. The plans have already been made, and the facade of the Dew bnilding wll present a most imposing architeotnral effeot.Some of the directors intend to visit Europe shortly in order to irfBpeot the colossal stores in the capitals of Europe, so that they nr ay model the interior of the new bnilding after the latest European pattern.

div.head: JUDICIAL APPOINTMENTS
div.p: Judge Cherakian Bey, of the Mixed Court of 1st Instance at Alexandria, has been appointed to the Mixed Coart of Appeal.
Judge Boutros Bey Youssef, Judge of the Mansourah Mixed Court, will replaoe him in the Court of 1st Instance.
Judge Naggari Bey, of the Mixed Court of 1st Iostance at Alexandria has been transferred to Mansourah.
Judge Mohamed Bey Mustapha will replace him here.

div.head: BOVINE TYPHUS IN EGYPT
div.p: Our Fayoum correspondent writes Bovine typhus is spreading rapidly among the animals in the Fayonm province. Many of them have been vaccinated, and I hope soon to be able to inform yon of the fffeotofthe serum used, and the likelihood of its being eff iotaal for the suppressions of the disease.
It has been deoided to. put the following notification on the patents and sanitary certi-ficates issued at Egyptian Ports:—
Le typhns bovin existe dans lea districts snivants ; Etsa, Fayoum et Embaba.

div.head: MEMORIAL SERVICE.
div.p: A memorial service for Mrs. Robert Mond. who died at Luxor on the 28th of Dumber last, was held at the Little PortUi d street Chapel, London, on Thursday last, at three o'clock.

div.head: THE NILE-RED SEA LINE
div.p: In our artiola of January 17 on the span bridges, it was inadoertently stated that 4he erection of these bridges was undertaken by the Sudan Government, and that they were riveted together by unskilled native labonr. Bote statements are erroneous, foi we are informed that Mr. George Urqabart contracted for the whole of the steel work on the line, bridges included, and that skilled Italian labonr was omployed in their construction. All the bridges are expected to be finished by the end or this year.

div.head: EGYPT AND TURKEY.
THE FRONTIER DISPUTE. RETURN OF THE NOUR - EL - BAHR.
div.p: Nothing has yet been heard or seen of the Coastguard Administration's oruiser Nour-el- Bahr. She left Suez towards the end of January for the gulf of Akabeh in oonnec'ion with the frontier dispute between Egypt and Tnrkey in the Sinaitio Peninsala, and had visions for one week on board. According Jqjhe prrgamme she should have been d^e back here on the 2nd inst., hnt not having returned the Ports and Lighthouses Administration's Aida was despatched on the 7th inst, in searoh for the mis-ing vessel. Nothing has up to now been ascertained and it is even rumoured that the Ottoman troops at Akabeh have detained her. but this is not officially oonfirmed. H.M.8. Diana is here in readiness to proceed should the necessity arise.
SUEZ Monday.
The Nonr-el-Bahr arrived here to-day.
The rnmonr that she was detained by the Turks at Akabeh is antrue.
A native oomtemporary states that the Turkish troops, who recently occupied El- Akaheh, numbered on Wednesday fOO men. On Thnrsdsy their numbers rose to 2,000, and Oa Friday to 6,000.

div.head: THE SUCRERIES
div.p: The creditors of the Sooi6t6 des 8uorerie« et de la Raffirerie d'Egypte met at the Cairo Mixed Courts at 3 p.m. on Saturday, Judge Tacit presiding. The Cairo Bar was well represented: Me. Carton de Wiart was present with Maitres Msrzbaoh, Padoa B«y, St Privat, Guillaumou and Martino. The Hon. A. Davey, M. Naville, and M. A. Gant liquidator of the 8ay Rsffinerie, with several members of the press, were also present.

On the Judge asking whether any proposals had been agreed to by the creditors, Me. Carton de Wiart stated that the majority of the oreditors h*d agreed to the proposals put forward under the oonoordat prlventif, which were then read by M. Tigliara.
After the proposals had been read Me. Carton de Wiart read the following documents
1. The new agreement between the Daira Sanieh Sugar Corporation and the Sucreries Co.
2. The agreement between M. A. Gault and the Snoreries Company under which all out-standing debts between the Say liquidation and the Company are annulled.
3. The Statutes drawn up by the Association of Shareholders in the defence of their own interests and rights.
The. "verification des pouvoirs" was then {>egan, and will probably last for the next two ortbrea days.

div.head: LAKE MENZALAH.
div.p: NAVIGATION DEVELOPMENTS

Great interest is being token at Port Said n the servioe t f boats which will shortly ply on Lake Menza'eh. The linking up of Port Said with Matarieh, and a farther extension later to Damietta, together with fatare possibilities of lock? into the Nile and Saez Canal, will complete a scheme calculated to lessen Considerably the cost of the transit of heavy goods from up oouutry. The opening up of new channels of trade to Fort Said promises to eubanco the valne of that plaoe as a oommer- oiai oentre. .

The Anglo-Amerioan Company has built to the order of the Menzaleh Capal Company, two passenger boats of 'he stern wheel tyre wi'h double promenade deoks, two paddle Lag toats. and six large cargo barges.

These boa s, bniltat Karpoutty. have already been seen on the lake, where they have caused a mild sensation, more especially among the Datives of Matarieh, apd the large number of people who lead a somewhat amphibious existence, earning a precarious livelihood by nesting fish.

div.head: GREAT FIRE AT MINIEH.
div.p: Oar Minieh correspondent writes : A great fire broke out on Friday in a ootton-ginning mill belonging to Mr. Erean, Takoob Effendi Barsoom and others. The fire lasted about three hours. By the energy of the Moudlr, Hakemda**, Mihm^ur and o her Government officials it was extinguished at tbe end of that time.
The oause of the conflagration is not yet, known. The losses are estimated at £ 10.000: a'd are oovered by insurance

div.head: ALEXANDRIA MUNICIPALITY
div.p: Up to the present the new candidates for the Alexandria Municipality are Mr. Miohel Salvago, Mr. H. P. Kingham and Mr. Tam- baooponlo, who distinguished himself during the oholera epidemic of 1896.
To THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
8ir,—I have read with mnoh interest the oorrespoudeDce and 'articles which yon have recently published with reference to our Municipality.

You very justly oom plain that no pub1 i city is given to the real savings and doings of hand to the amount of about £5, OOOstg. As our representatives in that body, so that we' are pleaded to find a few straws about, to see which way the wind blows; but I mnch regret the intemperate style which your correspondents on both sides have adopted; snch abase is not oalouUted to domuoh good, anonymous or otherwise. What advioe oould be more despicable than that of "Veritas'* to the electors, telling them to refrain from voting ? I believe that there is, theoretically, some fine or other punishment pro ided for MuDioipal Councillors who negleot to attend meetings, without some due oause. I should like to see a fine for each eleotor who neglected to record his vote, or. to see it taken from him and given to some worthier individual who could not afford to pay £76 a year rent. The right to vote should be a privilege mnoh sought after, and in my opinion the standard of rental should be mnoh reduced. It is true that in reoent times the landlords have pat their heads together to inorease the electorate to no small extent, and many tenants have had greatness most unwillingly throat upon them by seeing their rents raised from £*0 or £60 to £80 or £90 a year, perhaps snob may not be very eager members of the oon9titaenoy, hat let them flatter themselves that they have paid f ir a privilege which they should not fail to nse.

In one of your artioles you say that a well- known looal Councillor who reoently resigned was quite right in doing so, beoanse he was refused a seat on the delegation. I think it not unlikely that every member of the Municipality not on the delegation, thinks in his own inner oonsoionsness that he could do better than those who have that privilege. Therefore I oannot agree with yonr opinion; the motive referred to seems to me puerile The letter from the Vice-President of the Municipality appears quite as intemperate as thoee to which he replies. When a man speaks "ex oathedra" be should be a little more should like to know for ixptanoe how, or why, I who write to you anonymously so long as I do not slander my neighbour, or say anything which is antrue, am more despioable than a mmioipal oounoillor, who avails himself of that same anonymity (to propose or vote for municipal laws or regulations, which be knows will be widely objected to by his eleotors ?

To take a case in point. The inhabitants of the town are at the present moment put to great inoonveuienoe by the oab strike ; this strike was principally brought on by a sudden inorease of the tax on unnumbered carriages, to three times its former amount.

If the town oounoillor, in whose fertile brain originated 'his drastic method of filling the municipal o ffers, had spoken publioly, as he should have done, with the fear of bi* electors before his eye°, he wonld, possibly, have moderated his zeal,*and ^o^ld have contented himself vfi'h sojpe more reasonable and acceptable inorease ; it even seems to me extraordinary that it should not have ooourred to some of his oolleaguea, that multiplication by three to one made rather too big a pill to be swallowed oomfortably.

On the other hand, |t may be said that if the proceedings of municipal meetings are tp ba made public, some of the gentlemen, who have represented the town for many years, might deoline to act; to this I^should feel inolined to reply and a very good thing too.

The result of the recent general eleotion in England has shown in the most astonishing way, the evil of an eleoted body holding power too long ; the oonntry looked upon it, as a host might on friends who had been invited to tea, and who had stayed all night

It is only natural that much interest should be taken iu the coming municipal emotions ; the publicity of municipal proceedings, and if they oonvinoe the eleotors of their intention to do th'*s, they have good hopes of being returned.
As I do net speak, or write, "ex cathedra" nor am I responsible to any electors, I do not fell it any disgrace to sign myself, yonrs truly,
"ANONYMOUS."
Alexandria, Feb. 11th.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA SPORTING CLUB
div.p: A PROFITABLE YEAR
ANNUAL GENERAL MEETING.

The annual general meeting of the Alex andria Sporting Glub was held at the Khedivial Club on Fridav evening. The stewards present were Messrs. H. E. Barker, J. P. Rodooanachi, and A. 8. Preston and a few members. The minutes of last year's annual general meeting were read and oonfirmed. The Hoo. Sec. laid on the table the accounts and balanoe sheets for 1905 and read the following report:—

Gentlemen, I have the honour to lay before you the profit and loss a/o and balauoe sheet of the club for the year 1906 showing the considerable net profitfor th e year of over LE. 1.411 and funds last year, the figures of the previous year are shown for purposes of comparison, and to a large extent explain thenselves.I would,however, call your attention to the following items : The sum spent on games amounts to the substantial figure of L.E. 356, or L E. 32 more than last year; the amount debited to the "oourse a/o" is very considerably more than last year while the "oharges a/o" shows a considerable diminution, bnt it should be explained that this year various items of upkeep, which were last year dehited to the 'oharges a/o" are this year iuoludedin the "oourse a/o" which would moe properly be called the "clerk of the oourse a/o" The additional expenditure under this head has been involved by the increased cost of labour and of hire of mules, and by other extra work involved in Resting the grounds of the olnb in good order. The "extra expenditure a/o" consists this year in almost entirely one item, viz : the repairing, repainting and putting in thorough order of the grand stand ;, this work was undertaken on the advioe of two competent engineers who reported on the state of the stand ; and the olub is mnch indebted to Mr. Blagd»n for having kindly supervised the work. The office expenditure shows an inorease of L K 121 over that of last year, neoeas tated by the extra work involved, but as against this, the work - of the supervision of the pari mutnel, which last year cost the olub over L.B. '50, was taken over and worked from the office. The handicapper's fees which la9t year were paid, have this year been economised owing to the handicapping having been done by a handioap committee of three stewards. Turning to the items of reoeipts the subscriptions have again increased slightly by some L E. 83 The profit of racing, too, shows an inorease ofL.K >9 , made up of an inorease in the gate money and pari mutnel.

The buffet was this year let out to Vassili for L E. 150, and consequently shows a better profit than last year ; the other items remain much the same as last year with the exception of the interest on investments, which is naturally increased with the additional funds. The committee have again to express their warm thanks to H.H. Prince Mohamed Ibrahim, the Alexand ia Municipality, the Khedivial Club, the Alexandria and Kamleh Railway Co. and the Alexandria Athletio Sports club. The Municipality have* reoently generously increased their donation to L E. 100 of which part will be given in the form of a cap. The olub has now in band very substantial funds and can look forward consequently with equanimity to the prospect of having to mwt heavy expenses which will necessarily be involved when we are obliged to change premises. I have no more information to give sou as to this than I had last year. H.H. Prinoe Mohamed Ihrahim,as yon areaware,hfc promised to leave ns where we are until he can provide as with new premises,and his intention has not, as far as I know, been altered. The coming raoing season will show more big-races 'ban in the past chiefly oaueed by the addition of large prizes for European horses; 'his has been possible ohiefiy by the generosity of H.H. Prinoe Mohamed Ibrahim, who has given farther donations to the ^Xtent of L E. 400—for this object The rest of the racing will mostly follow ~ last year's programme. Various alterations have been made in the raoing rales of the ol«b daring the past year, ohiefiy with the view of settling various knotty points which have arisen os to the classification of horses, oowntrybred', barbs, eto, Owing to my time being folly OQOupled otherwise, I have found it impossible to oontinne as hon. secretary and treasnrer of the olnb ; the committee have accordingly appointed a paid secretary in the person of Mr. Walter Wilkinson who has during the past year assisted in the Sporting Clan office and had oharge of the acoonnts.

As already intimated to the committee, I propose to oontinne to exeroise on their behalf a general oontrol over such racing and other matters as need the supervision pf a steward, and the acoonnts will be periodically audited throughout the year. I have only to add that as usual Mr. Frank Haseldeu's servioes to the olub have been invaluable ; few who take part in the various sports such as polo, golf, tennis, etc., realise what an amount of time and trouble Mr. Heselden sacrifices to the elub with the result that the polo ground, tennis oonrts. golf greens, and other parts of the olnb premises are, I think you will agree with me, as thoroughly and efficiently kept up as is possible. The thanks of the Glnb are due to the other members of the Committee who have taken iu hand various branohee of sport, and the oloh will have mnch to regret in the Iras from the ranks of the stewards of Major Ludlow,, who so efficiently looked after the golf Af*er' thia Mr. Rodocanachi proposed, and Mr. H..K Barker seoonded, that the aoooonta and balance sheet he passed as being very aatbfiotory, which was oarried. The committee for 1906 was then ejected as follows : Prince Omar Paoha Tools'no, Prinoe Mohamed Ibrahim, Kha'il Pacha Khayat, Hassan Paoha Mohsen, Mr. H. E. Barker, Major Hopkinson, Mr. E. Karam, Baron Alfred de Menasoe, Mr. A\ 8. Preston, Mr, J. P. Rodooanachi. Mr. J. A. Soott. Mr.z M Sinadino, Mr. Godfrey H. Bwrker and Mr John Sinadino, Mr. F. 0' Ha°elden. (clerk of the conrseY Capt A. Lovcband, as representative of the 1st Royal Dablin Fn-iliers, and Mr. E. Giles, aareprp sentative of the Eastern Telegraph Company.

Mr. H. E Banker said that be had been requested by Prinoe Omar Tonesonn to propose a vote of thanks to Mr. A. S. Preston, on his resigning the honorary secretaryship of the clnb, for the very able way in which he h d oondnotedthe aflrrs of the olub during M. Daragon a 6U parfait dam Jtous. M.M. I last three years. This he had mnoh pleasure Monteox et Cotto se tost tfgalement distiuguli, io doing. The vote was passed unanimously

div.head: THE CAB STRIKE. LATEST PHASES. CARTERS' STRIKE PROBABLE.
div.p: The oab strike still oontinnes to the great inoonvenienoe of the publio of Alexandria The delegates of the drivers called at the Gonvernorat this morning and proposed a new tariff as follows. For not more than 15 minntes p.t. 2 (1 horee). and p.t. 3 (2 horses). For one hoar in the oity streets p.t. 6(1 horse), and p.t. 8 (2 horses). To Ramleh p.t. 20, and p.t 30 with 1| hour's waiting.

The President of the Municipality also discussed the question with the Commandant of Polioe, and it will be oonsiderel at the meeting on Wednesday provided that in the meantime the men resume work. Otherwise the question oannot be disouseed for some weeks.

It is feared that all the Alexandria carters will oome out on strike. These men have not yet deoided to strike, but they threaten to do so unless they are exempted from the Municipal Tax. The strike of these men would be most inconvenient, and would paralyse work on the quays.

Passengers arriving with luggage from Cairo and the Interior, at the Moharrem Bey terminus, are put to the gieatest inoonvenienoe owing to the utter laok of conveyances. The doctors are also seriously inoonvenienoed in going their rounds.
The general impression among, the cabmen appears to be in favour of the proposed emendation of the tariff.
The arbaghi's side of the question is given by a correspondent who writes —

Abdul Wahad tells me he now pays P.T. 80 per ardeb for barley and P.T. 100 per hemel fortibn for his horses. These prices are the highest we have seen, and are 50% more than the rates of two years ago. Everything else has also risen iu prioe.

The Municipality wish to exsot a tax of £5 on carriages and horses worth £10 '. The horse tax is raised from P.T. 60 to P.T. 60. Why a man with good carriage and horses should he taxed more heavily, is beyond my comprehension.

The tariff for oarriage hire is notoriously low in Alexandria, and the arbaghies are quite justified in striking against any inorease of taxes. The publio should protest and hold an indignation meeting in favour of the arbaghies.

Another complaint is that their horses, if run down, may be taken at the instanoe of the Sooiety for Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, kept in the hospital at a charge of P.T, 6 per day, where they sleep on the oold stones without bedding and, none too well fed, get worse instead of better.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: The Earl and Countess of Londesboroogh, whi intended leaving London for Egypt last week, have postponed their departure.
Lord Rathmore, aooompanied by several dircotors of the Suez Canal, has left London for Paris.
Sir Hugh and Lady Alice Shaw-Stewart an (a London oontemporary states) oomiog ont to Egypt on a visit to the Earl and. Countess of Cromer.
We hear that Azis Paoha Izzet will leave un an offioial mission to Egypt in the near future.
General Mashasha, the Abyssinian envoy, paid a visit to Lord Cromer on Saturday. Her, will leave Cairo to day for Jerusalem.
Lord Kimberley it oowiug to Egypt.

On Saturday ten 30.FraderiokTerryKowlatt oelebrated his forty-first bir thday. Mr. Rowlatt is the son of the late A. H. Rowlatt, one of Egypt's earlier prominent bankers, and was born at Alexandria. He was ednoated at Fettes College, Edinburgh, where he was known both as a scholar and a sportsman, and from where lie oarried off several prizes for swimming. He entered the Bank of Egypt in London in 1885 and was transferred to the Egyptian branch, * of which he aoted as manager, and he gave up that post to beoome snb-govefnofc of the National Bank of Egypt. He bsoame a Fellow > of the Institute of Bankers, London in 1902.«/. He married Edith, daughter of Mr. Cornish, C. M. G., of Alexandria, in May 1905.

Sir Walter Miéville writes as follows to the "Times" with referenoe to the late Sir Charles Cookson "In yonr fall and excellent notice of 8ir Charles Cookson, no mention of his kindly nature and sympathetic personality finds plaoe. I was his secretary for sevenpand^' his intimate friend for over 80 years, and 1 know it would gratify many of tie late Sir : Charles's friends if you oould find a corner for these lines. He was a man of experienoe, a man of pafts, a kindly gentleman, and an upright judge, and by his coartesy^ oharity, taofc, and loyal friendship, he endeared himself to a host of adnrrers and friqnds. He wad of the type of citizens who make cities great ; his heart, beat in unison with the great heart of suffering humanity, and when, at noon last Saturday, he passed pesoefully away, be did so in the oonso-. ling conroioksnesa that his memory wonld Kvp-fe long |n the Egypt he loved so well, that his many friends had but kindly affeetipnato thoughts for him—in a >ord, that he had •played the game' through bis long life without reproach.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: Captain W. A. I. K^ Kir g's Royal Rifle Corps, wh) has been seleoted for the adjutancy of the 21 st Middlesex V. R. C., bettor known as the Finsbury Rifles, was latterly serving with the 1st Battalion at Cairo. He £ot bis first commission in the R flss over nine years ago, and his comoany in December, 1901. He was attached to the West African Regiment, Sierra Leone, Jor some time, and shared in the expedition in that colony in 1898-99 (medal with olasp), and with the R fl «s he saw considerable service in the South African War, including the operations in Natal and the Transvaal (medal with tour clasps). It is freely stated that the grouped regimental district system, which Mr. Arnold- Forster introduced with a flourish of trumpets for greater efficiency and economy, will be dicoontinned, and the older'and well'tried system of independent regimental district, commanded by. colonels, will be reverted to. The grouped regimental district ay-tem has got a fair trial, and certainly it has not worked better, nor has it boon found to be cheaper than the system it displaced. It is one of the most unpopnlar of the alleged "reforms" carried out by the ex-War Secretary. On the evening of the 8th inst. a lecture entitled 'The De?ert Frontier of Lower Egypt" will be given in the Theatre of Leinster Honse, Kildare, St Dublin, by Lieutenant Colonel W. H. Rycrifc, 11th Haaears. Gen. the Rt. H in. Lord Grenfell, ex-8irdar of the Egyptian Army, and Commander in Chief in-Ireland, will preside. Lieutenant Colonel Ryoroft has an extensive knowledge of the country in question, having had a lengthened service with- hi regiment there, in addition to a The re armament of ihe Riyal Horse Artil lery and Royal Field Artillery is to be procee 1 ed with on 'he original Hues settled eightee months ago. It is stated that the new guns for both branches of the Royal Artillery will be completed in time for the entire ie-arinament by the end of next year. 'Hie new field gnn has given fairly satisfactory reanlts, and it praoti- cally does all that is olaime 1 for it, which cannot be said of some of the Continental field artillery, but the question of ammunition supply iu aotion still remains to be perfected. An offi rial statement relating to the laum h of the Dreaduonght by the King was issued at Portsmopth yesterday. His Majesty will arrive atPortsmoath on the, night of February 9. At a quarter past eleven next morning be '8 to leave his yacht at the South Railway Jetty and proceed across 1 ho dock yard in a speoial train. Guards of honour will be mounted at various points, and the whole route will be lined with sailors and marines,some 4,000 men being detailed for this duty. Decorated Venetian mai-ts are being erected' alongside the railway station, and tour triumphal arohes are being throw.) across it. The general public will be admitted to the dook yard,and may assemble at any point alongside the King's route, or near the Dreadnought. For privileged spectators stands are being erected, admission to 'hsss being by ticket. No tickets, however, will be needed to get into the dock yard. It is anticipated that many exoursion trains will be ran into Portsmi u'h, as the launch is regarded as one of the most important in the history of the British Navy

div.head: COLLEGE GORDON
div.p: FROM OUR SPECIAL CORRESPONDENT).

The day after our visit to Omdnrman, tbp Press party and the Legislative Councillor.- paid a visit to the Gordon College. In man* ways this was the most interesting sight cf all. The olose attention paid by the boys, Arabs. Blacks, Berberines and mixed races, to their teachers, their evident intelligence and eagerness to learn, and their bearing and discipline, delighted everybody, and the members of the Legislative Council were loud in their praise of the College. The system of teaching the curriculum of the various olasses, and the number, extraction,and aptitudes of the pupils must be treated separately and at length ; for the present I need only say that the object of the Gordon College i« to train young Sudanese to be of use to the Government and to the community, whether they afterwards become kadi«, schoolmasters or artisans, and thit the founders of the College forget that such an institution set down in the midst of a barbarous and newly conquered country had to have small beginnings. The College was certainly in its beginnings a primary school for black boys—it is difficult to see how it oould have been anything else, for whatever the capabilities of the Sudanese youths for absorbing higher or even secondary education without any tiresome primary training, these do not spring op from the soil, and I believe that European educational systems are based without exception on a course of primary education, which is generally supposed to be a necessary preliminary to more advanced study. The chief event in the history of the Gordon College during 1005 was the creation of an Upper School, which already oounts 15 pupils. This may not seem an immense nrm- her, hut education was to put it mildly— primitive at the time of the reoonquest, and Upper Sehools are not oreated in a day. Th« time, however, came when its oreation was considered feasible, and Mr.Currie the Director of Eduoation in the Sudan, having obtained the fundi, decided to oonsult the principal officials of the Technical Departments eKhe Sadan Government, vie., the Director of Works, the Director of Surveys, and ihe Director General (f Irrigation, with a view to learning their opinions as to the training most required in the rew Upper School, and as to what type of employ^ would be mest useful to the Government. The following reply from Mr. Dupnis, the Inspector General (f Irrigatir n in the Sudan deserves special attention by all who are interested in the spread of education not in the Sadan oi ly, but in all backward eouitries in the East. The principles it lays down for the training of engineers are equally applicable in Persia, Mesopotamia and the central Sudan, and the'future organisers of higher technical education in those regions will doubtless prof? by the results attained at the Gordon College. "Concerning the training of engineers and surveyorsIf all or even some of th* large works contemplated in connection with the training of the Nile and Irrigation in the Sudan are ever carried out, of which, I think there oan hardly be any dnubt. there most be an enormous deman i for men wi'h at least an elementary knowledge of surveying, land measuring and simple construction. The convenience and economy of being able to obtain suoh men looally, instead of hwing to tempt them away from Egypt by the offer of salaries often out of all proportion to their sooial standing and qualifications, would he immense, and theadvanfage to anew country like the Sudan of the oreation of a class with some engineering training oould not bat be very great. The special kind of qualification for which a demand would arise on the undertaking ofsnoh works as are contemplated would ba those that would fit a man to lay out lines, measure land area®, preoare simple plans, supervise earth works, lime and brick burning, and the construction of simple masonary works. An elementa'y knowledge of how. to keen accounts in any simple and oomprehensibl form, would be a most rsefal additional qualification. Imagine the case of the construction of a large canal system say in the Ghezira; the firar step would be the retting out of the lice* of the oanals, and the demarcation and expropriation cf the areas of laud they would occupy ; these lire* would extend certainly over hundreds,and probably over thousands of kilometres. The next step would be the execution of th- nesessary earthwork over there lines, an im mense business, and by no means so a mple a- is generally assumed], but one in which the presence of a capable 4upeivior can just m^fcp all the difference between the fini-hed work and strength, or being a permanent eyesore and source of trouble. Simultaneously with the earthwork a v*ry large number of bridges, regulators^ onlverts rest-houses, shelter-huts, e'e wonld be required : some of these works would nccef-suril require the presence cf tul'y trained engineer- of some experience ; hut for the innnmerah'e petty works an almost unlimited demand fv cheap but trustworthy supervision would arise. A very useful qualification wonld he a knowledge of lime and brick burning, w:th Heas as to what constitutes suitable limestone and briok eirth. where they are generally to be foaud, and how to set about converting the crude prsdnot into the finished article. In gnperv sing any snnh wo»k it would he necessary or desirable to kepp a running account (if expenditure; and for this an elementary knowledge of acoount keeping would he nseful. A very large demard for rongh but efficient temporary shelter huts and store-hauses, almost always arisen in the early stage of large under-takings ; and men with an intelligent eye for "he application of locally available material (generally mnd, grass, and in'erior timber) for "he construction of such buildings, are of great use. So far I have been considering the use of suoh men regarded as overseers or supervisors, and working as subordinate employes in a lyge organi-ed staff of ergineers ; but they would be at least equally nseful as petty contractors or gangers working at " piece work," •ndeed.the line dividing the temporarily engaged overseer on small pay from the petty contractor, often becomes very fine indeed. I think I have ssid enough to show the nature cf work f r which men of the most elementary qualifications are required, bet if you are prepared to go further, there is nothing to prevent suoh meu being trained and educat-ed into fully qualified engineers. For this course? 'he first necessity is deeper knowledge of mathematics, and a cultivated reasoning power, to permit of the formation of intelligent forecasts of the probable course of events under given conditions. The nse of the level is a more or IBRS me-chanical operation, and might easily b° acqnirpd and accurately practised by men of the first cla-s, without their quite understanding its inner bearings, and it is a qualification of the utmost value ; but I should not expeot reliable results from the use of a theodolite by a man of limited mathematical attainments; moreover. the use t f the theodolite is comparatively res triced. I have therefore divided the subjects in whieh training might in my opinion be attempted, into two classes, which I denote "Rub-overseers" and engineers", olassed respectively after an old Indian ctas^ifiobtion. I apologise beforehand for the obvious im-perfections of the lis's as submitted, and trust to yon to make gool their defijiencie* in the light of the explanations I have given above of the practical objects to be ob'ained. I have no experience iu the preparation of ooorses of instruction, or the elaboration of a college syllabus to guide me, and it is undoubtedly a delioate and d fficult business." ( To be continued,

div.head: LIFE IN NEW YORK
div.p: The dcotors r f New York are growing more and more alarmed about the proportion of sudden deaths, mainly fr m heart disease, and this they attribute to the killing pace at which New Yorkers live. Five and twenty years aco, they poiDt out, the death rate was only 13J per cent, wlnreai in 1904 it was ' 7 per cent., aud the ratio is inorearing. "The awful con-dition of life in this city," remarked an eminent physician to the writer, 'is respon-sible for the awf il proportion of sudden deaths, Men eat ton fast an 1 work aud play too hard. "To see them rushing up the staircases of the elevated railways and subways, and tearing after at>e*t cars thou.h here are hunlreds of other oars behind withm a few yards—all this is traly deplorable. I often recommend to my patients—b isy merchants, many of them, mind you—to lie quietly in bed for a who'e d«y fl»t on their back so that their heart may lo e forty thousand beat* in that time, thereby regulating many an evil condition." Phe writer ta'ke l on this subject with D-. A. T. Wes'on, the wall-kmwn coroners' phy-sician in Nuw York Citv, who told him that la-t year there were more tfhan 3,000 oa»e of men filling dead or dyiug hardly les sud-denly from heart failure—an ino'evo f nearly 6 v> oase* over the previous year. Aud during the past three months alone there were over 1,70 > cases to which ooronera' physicians' no'ioewi* called, so that thia yeir bids fair to snrpa-s all others. Su'oide3, too, are i oreasing at aa appalling rate, and when one observes the frenzied crush in the subways and overhead trains; the mad desire f)r rapid transit anywhere and everywhere ; the 'plunging automobiles, the paokel mobs hanging from car traps in the street oar*, one cannot wo-der 'hat this should be so. Then, again, the ' quick lunoh" restaurants where men literally hurl food into their stomachs, standing up, are ominous signs of the times. There is. too, th appaling uproar of the city with its tooting motor cars, ■ clanging bells, rattling drays, whistling fire-engines, thanderons overhead railways, and general frantic uproar-all thi« is most wearing to the nervous system. "New Yorkers," remarked another authority, ' are driving them«eive», a» d being driven, hke beasts of burden. They w >rk like dynamos all day, and p'ay like fools all night. They rn*h home from work tired ont, bolt their dinner, a id then tear out in search of pleasure nr til tho small hoars. Noxt morning th°y have recourse to powerful drugs-the greatest hpart- denressnr known ; and when they die suddenly, h*lf-a-d' zsn newcomers take 'heir place, and so we do not notice the terrible waste of life.

div.p: Delicious, Wholesome and Refreshing, Prepared from the Ohotoeot Weet Indian Uroe Fruit

To THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE. J Sir—While I was qnietly having my lunoh j in one of the houses of the Rue de la Forte Rosette, I was suddenly startled by a howling noise which seemed to be produoed by some war-ship passing in the street at great speed. The thought struck me that it might be some new fire-engine racing to a conflagration, but although I had made the few steps to the window as1 quickly at possible I could only just get a glimpse of a motor disappearing in the distance. The motor was not even one of the very large ones, but the howl it gave made the whole neighbourhood sharidar and the he*da ot all the people in the street were turned in the direction where it had disappeared in a oloud of dufrt. I understood that this new noise iu the streets of Alexandria meant that a man was driving through the thorough fares of the town at about the speed of an oiled fla-h of lightning, and that he was warning great and small, ohildren, women and men, old ladies with gout and yoong without, carriages and oarts, busses and all other* vehicles, oats and dogs, to hop quiokly, or hasten in some manner, out of the way he had chosen for his mad career. He must have been aware himself that he was driving a little too quickly to give common mortals the neoessary time to get out of bis way, if not warned at a great distance. I will not speak about the necessity to oome to a decision about the speed with which it is allowed for a motor to drive throngh densely frequented streets, for I have heard from competent sources that the polioe as wall as the Municipality have given up all hope of control ling this nuisance cf reokless driving of Autos; but what I should like to kaow is:—Will it be allowed to use this howling machine in the town of Alexandria also daring the night, when people who do not drive in Autos and still stiokto the RntTdibvia® habit of walking on foot, try to get a litt'e rest. This rest is already greatly curt fed by the furions driving of carriages and the oraoking of whips aft*r the theatre or some other amusement is over. The above bespoken common mortal is already sufficiently frightened ont of his sleep by the usual "Toot" of the motor, when the unease or Vieillesse dorde, belated at the olub or the theatre seek to get home as quiokly as possible, or are speeding to some Dew p^sure We know that a man in an Auto considers himself so f»r above the non- be-antoed humanity that considerations of the regard due to his fellow citiiens do rot trouble him much. We km w that egotism is waxing wild in modern times, when ft soems to be merely a S'gn of weakness to oonsider what harm yon may be doing to others by the pnrsuit of your own, often very futile, p'ea sures. An example of this may easily be found on a Snnday afternoon, when Autos, laden with representative* of the higher society from whom fair thinking might be expeotei^ are driven at a hurling speed through the rows of carriages, throwing clouds of dost and ill- smelling smoke into *he faces of others who by a qniet promenade-drive try to get a little frei-h air. The Chaonbhe k oheval gallop* afer the Arab who drives his oart a little qnioker than he ought to, but for the Auto his horse is not quick enough. And of what use would it be ? People in motors are immune from the cooseqnenoes of laws or regulations made many year* ago when motor* had not yet been invented. In Earope it is forbidden fir sfeam->hips to blow their whis'les and ring their bells daring the night on the river in the vioinity of towns. In the "Avis k la Navigation" for this port the last Artio'e (No. 18) reads as follows: "Il eat strictunenfc ddfeudu aux navires de fiire usage de sirknes à vapeur dans le port iotk- rieur et dans l'arsenal " Bat after all, motors are not ship*, which is best proved by the fact that not thorc who are in them,but those who are out of them get mo it sick of them. Let us hope that one day Artio'es may be made for motors also.—I am, dear Sir, like the greatest part of mankind, A SUFFERER. Alexandria, 8th February

div.head: MUTINY ON H.M.S. CARNARVON
div.p: Alexandrians will be surprised to bear that 'here has lee* some trouble on H. M 8, Carnarvon, which remained here recently for some weeks. The Malta correspond ert of the "Daily Mail", witing on January 27'h, states :— There was an ugly outbreak of insubordination yesterday on board the armoured eraser Carnarvon, one rf the new County olass, com manded by Sir George Warronder, Bart. As usual, the naval authorities are very reticent in the matte", and details are difficult t»obtain. I'seems, however, that a growi' g di*c mtent am mg a section of the ship's com pany culminated yesterday afternoon in the throwing overboard of some aiming right belonging to the 6 in. gnns. Several men are believed to ba under anrest, and the officers and crew are confined to their ship for the present. A court-martial on the offenders will pro-bably be held in a few days. '

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY
div.p: RIPLB SHOOTING. CAIRO BRITISH RIFLE CLUB.

On Friday, 25^h nit. a short range spoon was won by Mr. M. P Percival (Allowed 6 P'dnt*) with the score of 89, after a tie with Mr. W. D. Blake ftctateih). On Friday. 2nd inst. the olub shot eft a match against Khartoum Rifle Club, the arrangement being tbafc each olub was to shoot at their own range on kme of three named dates. Khartoum will shoot later in the moDth. The weather was very unfavourable for aboetiog, as a strong rear wind raised olouds of stud, which' seemed to upset the shooters. Cairo soore* ore given below. Total ' 620 On Saturday Mr. W. V. Shearer won a spoon with 29 + 32 + 80 = 91, Mr. Craig being naxt with 31 + 31 + 28 = 90 Mr. Shearer has also won a Milton Silver Badge. FOOTBALL. A football match between the Railway Institute and the M.M.P. was played on Friday last at Gheziret Badrane, and the game ended in a win for the home team by 2—0 goals.The continuous rain which fell during the game rendered the ground very slippery and muddy, and consequently proper football was a matter ot impossibility. The two goals were scored iu the opening half of the game.MoCairns was referee.

div.head: THE DAILY MAIL YEAR BOOK
div.p: This handy litt'e annual has now reached its sixt» D8oo. and we find it thoroughly up-to-date especially in Seotion I., which deals with the questions of the day. Although the date at which it went to pret>s did not allow r f the insertion of the names of the new Liberal ministers, the faot of Sir II. Campbell-Bannerman's acceptance of office is neftified, and the remarkable forecast of the anricipated Liberal and victories made by Mr W.T.Stead in his estimate of the remit the general election—below the mark as, to everybody'* surprise, it turned out—is given in detail, and forms an excellent example of editorial foresight.' Information on eve y oonoeivable political subject isgiveD, and Eduoation, Poverty, Labour, Arbitration, eto., are all treated on. Section Il.is entirely devoted to the Fiscal controversy, *he oves for Protec-tion and Free Trade being dealt with by Mr. J. L. Garvin and Mr. L. G. C. Money. M.P. Altogether pages ate devoted to the question, of which p'obab'y most people are by this time rather tired, although at any moment they may require to refer to the facts connect-ed with the controversy. Section III. is called "The Empire," page after page being filled with trade statistics. Seotion IV. deals with Foreign Affairs ; V. with personal matters, oo wise biographies of men and women of note from the King to Joha Burrs being given. Seotion VI. treats of Finanoe, VII. Agriculture and Food, Vlll.Commeroe, while the remainder of the book is devoted to the consideration of snoh subjeots as Religion,Education,Travel, and Tmffio all over the world, the armies and navie* of every Power, Local Government, Telephones and Telegraphs, and finally Sports. The book end*, instead of begins, with a calendar, which we think a mistake, as iu works of this character people naturally expeot the almanack to take fftafc place, and to find it without having to oonsult an index. The handbook is dearly printed and is published at the moderate pricAof Is. 6d.

div.head: A TOUCHING TALE.
div.p: Eighteen months ago a deserted infant was found by the roadside at Clonghton, a village outside Scarborough. The child was taken nare of by Mr. John L?adley, a farmer, and member of the board of guardians, and tie mother having teen traced, she was prose- outed. The o'ronmstanoes surrounding the girl's downfall were tonnd to be very pathetic, and as she hid been more ainnel against than sinning, no punishment was i» flicted. A ww4paper report r f the faots wa* read by a gold miner iu British Columbia, and his heart was so touched that he forwarded an offer of marriage, together with a sum of £30 for the girl's passage out. She went, and was married the day after Bbe landed. Last week she returned for the child, which had been ado; t'd by a sympathetic carter's wife at Selmer, and on Saturday the happy mother and child sailed from Liverpool to rejoin the husband. By the time the mother regains British Columbia she will have travelled forne 8,000 miles on the child's acoount ftldiifi.

div.head: COMMISSION MUNICIPALE
div.p: (Communication Officitlle)
La Commissinn Municipals s'est rennie le 10 fdvrier 1006 4h. p.m. sons la presidence de M. A. Balli.

Presents : MM. Ahmed Paoha Yehia, Ahmed Bay Eyoub, Em. Benachi, Hussein Bey Riaz, Macaulay, A. Cumbo, L. Esooffier, P. Fondori, Baron A. de Menaace, 0. Rothacker, Dr. J. Schiess Bey, E. Stross, Soliman Bey Abani, Dr. G. Valensin, G. Zervudaohi, 0 Zoiro, membres, W. P. Chataway, adminiatra teur, I Sedky Bey, secretaire.
Mention eat faite de l'envoi à t6ue lea mem du procfea-verbal de la Delegation da 9 janvier 1906.

A l'occaaion d'ane demand© ( d'explioations de M Fenderl sur lea causes quteont determine la gr» ve des cocbers de fiacre, la commission, aprcs un echange d'idees, oharge\'admini8 trateur d'entendre les griefs de oette corporation et de lui fair© rapport a la prdchaine slance desea observations et de ses propositions, s'il y a lieu.

M. de Menasoe ayant demande pour qnelle raison la route de Ramleh n'avait pas 6 6 arrosfee, en partie, oes derniers jours, l'adminis trateur rlpond que cette interruption est dfte ~k ce que le service comptait faire des essais de goudronuage qui nsessitentl'asschementprai- lable de la route, mais que les essais ayant CA ajournea l'arrosage rig □ lie r a ete repris.
Une interpellation de M^ie Menaace, an sujet des heures d'extinotion bees de gaz, eat renvoyde pour explication! à provoquer de la part de la Compagnie du Gaz.

Ladministrateur, a propos d'ane informa- . tion parue dans la pretse et de laquelle il rcsulteraut que les pompiers se seraient rend us en retard sur leslieuxdasi istre lors da dernier incendi© qui a Ic'ate à Minet el-Bassal, tient 4 faire remarquer que l'incendie n'a pas signals© la brigade par les interessls, et que e'est par hasard qu'an pompier ayant vu de loin les lueurs de l'incendie, en a immediate- moat avisl la brigade, qui a aussitdt aooouru.
Le vice-president fait rapport sur les recla-mations electorates pour Fannie 1906.
Eu plus des 1237 dleoteurs dljk insorits dans la liste Itectorale generate, il y a lieu sur les demaudes pre sen ties, d'admettre 163 noms comma ayant les quality voolues.
Four la liste des propriltaires, il y a lien d ajouter aux 398 lleotears, dljk insorits, 19 nouvelles demaudes.
La Commission adopts le rapport du vice president et dloide de porter les nouveanx iuscrits dans une liste supplanentaire afin de leur permettre de prendre part anx Elections de cette annle.

Une quostioa ayant ete sonlevde an sajet des peroonues qui se rlclament des loyers payls par ies societls dont elles font partie, la Commission decide d'admettre pour cette annle les reclamations basles sur des loyers de oette nature tel que oela rlsalte des conclusions du rapport du vice-president.

Elie eatime toutefois qu'il y a lieu pour Tavener de prloiser dans un rfeglement d'appli-cation les conditions sous leequelles devraient 6tre admises les demandes to□ chant certaines situations qae la loi fe tec to rale n'a pas tranohle, notamment la question des sooietes.
Cette etude sera entreprise par le Comite da Contentienx.
La Commission nomme MM. Esooffier,Foster et Rotbaker comma Comite d'examen adjoint a la Delegation pour le nonvean post© d'ingenieur eleotrioien.
Elie dlaigne MM. Padoa Bey, de Menasoe et Mabfouz Bey oomme Comite d'examen adjoint au mfime College ponr le nouveau poste de Deiegueaux contraventions.
La Commission ouvre an credit de L.E. 2000 à prelever sur le budget extraordinaire ponr la mise en adjudication de la fonrnitnre de 10,000 m. l./de bordure.

M. Esooffier 'interpelle an sujet de la note de ladministrateur et des differentes decisions de la Delegation et da Comite des Travaux Publics an sujet du service technique et des conditions dans leequelles doit s'effeotuer la mise a la retrain de Dietriob Bey, ingenieur en ohef de la ville, a la suite de ses longs services.

Aprfes an echange d'idees, la Commission decide de mettre an oonoours le poste d'ingenieur en chef de la Municipality et de donner • Dietrich Bey le titre dTogfenienr oonseil de la Ville. La Delegation d'accord aveo leoomite das T avaax pablios s'oooapera de la fixation de ia retribution fe accorder à Dietrich Bey et des voies et moyens ooncernant la mise au oonoours du poste vacant et en fera rapport it la Commission.
Une seance aura lien meroredi 14 ffevrier 1906 à 4 h. p.m. pour la continuation de l'ordre du jour.
La seance eat levee it 8 b. p.m.

A Londres, le oonsolide anglais a olOtnrfe hier it 90 3/4, soit en baisse de 1 /8. Par oontre, l'Unififeeagagnfe 3/8 it 105 1/8. La National Bank est renseignfee en rlaotion de 1/4 de livre it 27 7/8etOa Daira de 1/8 it 17 7/8. L'Agri- cole est restfee inohangfee à 10 1/8.

L'exposfe qa'il oontient da bat et des pers-pectives de l'entreprise est tellement clair, tellement explioite, qa'il n'y a rien à y ajoater.

Cette affaire fetant lanofee sons nos anspioes, nos leotears oompreadroat la reserve qui noas est iinposfee de oe cbel. Tout oe qae noas poa- vous dire, o'est qae o'est ane affaire sferiease, trfes sferieasemeat dirigfee, et qae les affaires qa'ellea dfes à present en main lai assarent des bfenfefioes important© et presque immfediatement rfelisables.
